question.text: Earth receives <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1400</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></math> of solar power. If all the solar energy falling on a lens of area <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></math> is focussed on to a block of ice of mass <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>280</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math>, then what is the time (in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>min</mi></math>) taken by the ice to melt completely? [<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi>fusion</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>105</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>kg</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>]

solution.text:
Heat required to melt the block

= (0.28kg) (3.3 x 105 J/kg)= 9. 24 x 104J

Heat received per second = (1400J/ m2 ) (0. 2m2 ) = 280 J

Time taken (in minutes) =9.24×104280×60  = 5. 5
